title: CTRL0000916061 - Transcribed Interview of Stephen Michael Ayres, (June 17, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The interview in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 1:36 p.m.
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
This is the transcribed interview of
Mr. Stephen Ayres, conducted by the House Select Committee to Investigate the
January 6th Attack on the United States Capitol, pursuant to House Resolution 503.
At this time, I would ask the witness to please state your full name and spell last
This will be a staff-led interview.
And members of the committee, of course,
may join and ask questions if they choose to do so.
But, right now, all you have on is
investigative counsel and no members in the room right now.
At this time, could counsel for Mr. Ayres please state their name for the record?
Eugene Ohm on behalf of Mr. Ayres.
There is an official reporter transcribing the record of this interview, so I'm going
to ask that you please wait until each question is completed before you begin your
So it's important that you answer each question with an audible, verbal
I'll help you out with that.
response from the witness or negative response from the witness.
And we will try to wait until your response is complete before we ask our
The stenographer cannot record nonverbal responses, such as shaking
If I see you shaking your head, I'll say positive
We ask that you provide complete answers based on your best recollection.
That's it, just your best recollection.
If the question's not clear, just ask me for a
If you do not know the answer, please just let me know.
First, it's important you understand that this interview is
If at any time you would like to stop speaking with us, that is your choice.
Similarly, if at any point you need to discuss something with your attorney in private,
please let us know, and we'll take a break so you can have that conversation.
This interview is not under oath, but because this is a formal congressional
investigation, you are obligated under Federal law to tell the truth, the same as if you
were speaking to the FBI or DOJ.
It's unlawful to deliberately provide false information
So, for this interview, providing false information could result in criminal
Third, you're not obligated to keep the facts of this
interview and what we discuss confidential.
You are free to tell whomever you wish that
you met with us, including the prosecutor or judge on your case, or you can tell no one at
The select committee is separate and independent from the DOJ.
So we have no involvement with the prosecutions, and the DOJ is not a partner to the
And we're not agreeing to submit anything on your behalf to the judge.
make any representations whether if you tell the judge you met with us, if the judge
would be more favorable for you during sentencing.
We're also not a party to your criminal case.
And then, last, we have agreed with your attorney not to share
the substance of what you say with the DOJ prior to your sentencing.
enforcement was unaware of or if we had reason to believe that you lied during the
interview, then we would be obligated to tell DOJ or another appropriate law
that may prompt questions from the judge about what you said and whether it's
consistent with your prior statements and acceptance of responsibility.
starts asking questions, we may get asked to respond and divulge what you said.
So, if you tell us about evidence about a crime we thought law
And, if you tell the judge you met with us, please understand that
But those are the only exceptions, so is that clear?
So, again, before we get into the meat of the questions, let us
know if you need any breaks or if you would like to discuss anything with Mr. Ohm, we'll
And, again, I'm the only investigative counsel on right now, but some might join.
If so, there may be multiple people asking questions at that point.
someone to repeat something, please just say that, and we will repeat the question or
So can you tell us a little bit about yourself?
So like, how old are you?
How long have you lived there?
Currently reside in the State of
Been over here on and off 5 years here and there.
right on the other side of the border.
So Ohio, Pennsylvania is right here; the line's right
So people bounce back and forth for work and whatnot.
Yeah, about an hour north of Pittsburgh, about an hour south of Cleveland,
Western PA, eastern Ohio, that Allegheny, Pitt area?
like dead center of them two so.
Went to votech while I was there for
Got out of high school, and I started my -- I worked at KraftMaid Cabinetry
for 20 years, up until this stuff came about, as a supervisor there for 4 years.
That's really about it right now.
I'm starting my own construction company.
kind of -- all this Capitol stuff kind of put a -- for lack of better words, damper on kind of
really the work outlook since all this stuff started.
industry pretty well, so I'm getting in business with a buddy of mine and getting a
So I do know the construction
So let's go back then to the election of 2020, leading up
So we're going to ask you pretty much just questions of what you
were thinking or what you were seeing or what you were feeling leading up to
of your views now in retrospect.
And then we'll go through January 6th as well.
Then we'll end it with kind
So, going back to the 2016 election -- or 2020 election -- not 2016.
not going back that far -- but to the 2020 election, how would you describe your level of
political engagement throughout former President Trump's term?
It was a lot more -- I wasn't very political until I got on -- well, really social
media I feel that's what really got me more political, more following politics and whatnot.
Facebook, lnstagram, Twitter, you know, with that -- that whole outlook on there, you
Everyone's expressing their views and opinions, and it gets very,
A lot of people get very fired up about it.
up until the social media and stuff, I really didn't follow politics, you know, all that well so.
I just didn't follow politics as hard until President Trump,
you know, took office I think.
Was it fair to say, though, that you started following on social media when
So why did you start following it more hard when
I'm not sure if it was just social media, or if I just liked the way, you
know, he presented himself with, you know, his views and beliefs.
kind of what made me start following a little bit more.
following them a little bit here and there back when Obama was in office, but not as
watching it and following it a lot.
Because I was a little bit
It's like, once Trump got in office, kind of seemed like it was like a lot.
I was reading up on it every day, researching stuff
But it definitely took off, I would say, when he probably, you know, became
And you started following it -- and just let me know if this is
wrong -- because you personally liked President Trump and his style of leadership?
I'm going to touch on some of the social media stuff actually very shortly,
That's basically, you know, a way to sum it up.
but before I get to that, did you read like traditional print media, like the Wall Street
Journal and New York Times about politics?
I always strayed away from the mainstream media.
one of them people that research everything.
opinion, but I kind of try to stay away from the mainstream media because in my opinion
they're going too far left, too far right.
I research it all, then I form my own
I like to research and form my own opinion.
Did you watch any television news?
I don't know what you consider mainstream media.
So I'm just going to make
Did you watch any television channels to get your information?
I would watch Fox News, you know, ABC, CBS, NBC, you know, the main
and then alternative channels on like VouTube.
I'd watch them, but mainly it would be like Fox News
I watched a lot of -- follow a lot of
That's where I get a lot of it.
So, on VouTube then, what channels, if you can just give us a few
you watched to get your information?
started, I just quit following politics all together.
There was just a couple talking heads on there basically that, you know, they put their
It was a little bit of everything, watching a little bit of everybody.
I would check out Fox News on there.
I really can't even think of their names off top -- once all this stuff
So I have trouble even remembering.
I can't really narrow it down to just any one particular person.
I've seen some of his stuff, but I wasn't a real big fan of him.
Can you give me one example, then, just a name of one person at least that
Like Candace Owens, I'd follow her.
Charlie Kirk, I'd follow him now that I
Some of Ben Shapiro's stuff, but I don't think he was quite as big then as
So, mainly, like, most of the conservative people that are on there, the bigger
So, going back to the social media, which social media applications did you use
mostly to read about politics or did you follow politics on?
I would say it was probably Facebook.
was on and reading up on politics and all that.
That was like my main one that I
I'd say Facebook was the number one.
Trump got banned on Twitter and Face book, if that's the one.
mess around with it because the whole layout and everything, I just really wasn't big -- I
think I did try getting on there, but I didn't do much with it after, you know, I got in there
and seeing how it was and whatnot.
I just -- I think -- I'm not sure if I got on that one or not, or if I did, if it
main that I really was on.
Did you follow anybody on Parler?
I don't know if they put that out after
I joined it, but I didn't
I liked Reddit, but I wasn't -- didn't -- I just found
I haven't had Reddit up until within the last probably year and a
Other than that, it was Facebook, lnstagram, and Twitter were the three
So I hear -- I'm still going to go through a few to make sure.
I don't think I have any -- I've heard of it, but I don't think I'm on
there or had even been on there.
So you follow things on Twitter?
So you did watch news shows on YouTube?
TheDonald.win, did you ever get on that website?
Nope, never heard of that one.
And the last one is Wimkin, W 1-m-k-i-n?
I've never even heard of that one.
I never heard of that one.
I don't believe I've heard of that one as well.
I think you might have touched on this so just to make sure we
If you had to pick one or a couple of these sources, which sources did you
They would have been -- it would have been Face book and Twitter would
have been like the top two.
Because I know you mentioned some of the shows --
Following them, yeah, and the videos from there.
I wasn't real active on YouTube.
I just watched videos and comment
Facebook and Twitter, I'd post stuff every day and stuff like that.
And did you get to the YouTube links through Face book a lot, or would you
I think a little bit of both, you know, because a lot of times, you could just tag
the YouTube videos right into Face book.
So, you know, if you watch a video, it's gonna
carry you right over into YouTube.
Facebook and then, you know, maybe got shifted over to YouTube from there, from the
So probably a lot of times I caught it right from
I'm assuming, but correct me if I'm wrong, that you followed former President
Trump on these social media apps?
And, just to be clear, which site did you follow him on?
I followed him on Facebook, Twitter and probably lnstagram.
the three that I think I had him on.
So, right after the general election 2020, so right after November and the
days afterwards, did you believe that the election had been stolen from former President
What made you think that the election was stolen?
pinpoint, I guess, when did you start to believe the election was stolen?
Probably that night when they saw that huge drop for Biden in the middle of
the night when everybody was sleeping.
to me that that was even possible.
That's where it just, you know, it looked crazy
I think it was that night myself.
Was there anything else, I guess, as the weeks continued after this
that made you -- I guess even more confirmed your thoughts that the election was
Just from posts I follow online talking about the
voting machines, how certain voting machines were used in bigger districts.
turned around, they used smaller voting machines or like a smaller company.
certain, you know, big, you know, big districts, that the bigger districts seemed like they
were using certain voting machines there.
that kind of got me thinking, oh, maybe the thing was rigged, you know?
That's the stuff I seen a lot
Did you participate in any rallies or anything after the election?
So you didn't go to any "stop the steal" rallies in Ohio or Pennsylvania,
Did you follow the "stop the steal" movement?
I've only been to that one rally, and that was January 6th.
That was the first one I've ever been to.
I just found out about it with my friend, Matthew Perna, when
If you want to go, we've got room.
I've never been to a Trump rally before that.
figured that was going to be his last one, him leaving, you know, from the Presidency.
So I wanted to go to at least one Trump rally before he was out of the Presidency.
I'm sorry to hear about Mr. Perna's death.
I thank you for talking to us, and even, I know it can be difficult probably to
And I didn't want to make this assumption; Mr. Perna was your friend, a
talk about a friend that's been lost.
If you don't mind me asking you, how has that impacted you, Mr. Perna's recent
It messed with me a lot, you know?
If you don't mind, when we get to the end when we're thinking about things
in retrospect, I might ask you just a few questions of how it might have impacted you and
how -- if it might have changed you.
want to highlight, I might get to that later on in this interview.
If the answer's no, feel free to say that.
So you didn't attend the November 14th rally in Washington, D.C.; that's
And you didn't attend the December 12th rally in Washington, D.C., either?
So walk us through, then, the factors that influenced your decision to come
I know you came down on January 5th.
But what were you thinking about when you came?
I basically was just coming for the rally because, you know, the President
Hey, come down to D.C., stop the steal rally.
perspective the actual name of it.
Like I didn't even put it into
I was basically going down just to see, you know, the
And, you know, like I said Mr. Perna -- and he had some friends and
You know, that was only the thing, going down there to see that.
Like I had no idea -- I don't know if it was planned to walk over to the Capitol
then straight over to the Capitol.
Mr. Trump's like "let's march over to Capitol and show our support" or whatever, this and
that, that's when we decided to walk over.
I don't recall ever hearing that, but like we didn't plan on going to the rally,
Like, I don't remember ever hearing or nothing about
I was just going for the rally.
Then, at the end, when, you know,
So it wasn't like I even planned out, that I
Did you think that former President Trump was going to join you all at the
I don't know if I thought he was going to or not.
for 10, 15 minutes after the actual rally ended.
know if I thought he was going to actually be over there or anything like that.
And then we walked over there.
We'll get to the day of a little later.
Is it fair to say you came to D.C. with Mr. Perna and his family and friends because
President Trump was going to be speaking?
And was there anything specific that former President Trump said in the lead
up to January 6th that made you want to come to D.C.?
Like, was there something he said?
Was there a tweet, anything that really made
Nothing that I can think of.
You know, I just saw that it was going on.
was like, you know, it would be cool to go watch him talk.
I don't remember ever hearing or seeing anything where I felt like, oh, I
Do you remember the December 19th tweet where he said, "Will be wild"?
Do you remember the tweet from President Trump on December 19th
where he said, "Be there, will be wild"?
I know I put out something like that:
It would be cool to be
Like I didn't think of it being like something crazy was gonna happen.
Hey, it's going to be cool.
So, when you said, when you put out there "will be wild," I'm just going to
ask you, what were you thinking?
What was going to be wild about it?
Just how many people were going to be there, the rally, and all that.
never -- never like pre-gamed or planned anything leading up to that.
cool, we're going there, just like if I was going to a concert; it's going to be wild.
like my way of saying it's gonna be fun; it's gonna be cool.
the Capitol was going to take place.
I don't even barely know them that well.
I don't even remember their names.
If you don't remember, that's fine.
I didn't mean it like in -- suggest something like what happened at
Hey, this is gonna be a good
Other than Mr. Perna, who did you travel to D.C. with?
Like, I didn't hang out with those guys.
But the people that went with him, I never met them before in my
So Mr. Perna was kind of like the center, and you were friends with him, and
he had other friends that came down with you all?
I was kind of like the last addition add on to them
Hey, if you want to go, you can come.
If you had to put a date on it, when did you decide you were going to come
It was a few weeks before.
I'm not sure exactly how long.
been 6 weeks before, maybe a month.
I don't know like the exact time when I was
like -- I want to say it was like a few weeks before, but I can't remember exactly.
I would say, at the latest, probably like 6 weeks before, I believe, at
But I'm thinking it was closer like a couple weeks beforehand, but I'm not a
I guess, how were you tracking information for the rally?
tracking it on Facebook as well?
If I would have been following any of it, it would
Were you aware of any buses or caravans taking people to D.C. for the rally?
I think I remember seeing or hearing about that.
You didn't know anyone personally who used these caravans or buses to
Did any elected officials have any impact on your desire to travel to D.C.
Did any other I guess elected Congressman or State officials impact your decision?
I don't recall like hearing someone saying, like, "you should
be down there on January 6th" or anything that would have impacted my decision, you
know, to go down there for the rally.
I guess another just piggyback on that question, though, were there any
politicians during this time period other than President Trump that you really followed
and thought highly of, I guess, while this "stop the steal" or certification challenges were
I mean, I followed the -- like the big conservative, like, talking point heads
Like Ted Cruz, and -- I don't even know their names off the top of my head.
I'd follow the ones that were always speaking out kind of in his favor because there
But I would probably say I followed them on, you know, Facebook
Ultimately, what was your goal, right?
You decided to come on January 6th; what was your goal or what were you
It's a little bit of a drive; 5, 6 hours from Ohio?
So what was your goal in coming?
My goal was just to go -- my personal goal was just go see him speak at his
I always seen him on TV.
I've seen the rallies on, you know, YouTube and stuff.
So you viewed this as almost as like his last speech?
My perspective, I just wanted to see him speak one time before he
wasn't going to get a chance.
That's how I looked at it.
I figured he was leaving office; I
I wanted to make one that was like up here in Erie, but I
And I didn't even try that hard.
But I figured this was going to be
his last one, so I definitely want to see it.
So, in your mind, though, when you came, you thought he was going to be leaving
I know we've heard former President Trump talking about a big reveal on
office, or did you think there was a chance he could remain in office?
Like, I know it was like -- they called it the "stop
the steal" rally and stuff, but I didn't really think that it was going to be like, "hey, I'm not
leaving"; you know what I'm saying?
his big reveal was going to be; you know what I'm saying?
to be, like, "Oh, guess what, I'm staying," or something like that.
I'm not sure what it really would have been, what
I'm not sure if he -- like I thought he was going
You know, he kind of built
So going more to January 6th itself.
Did you stay in the city, or did you stay in the
We stayed at a hotel in the city, handful of blocks away.
walking distance but probably took 15 or 20 minutes to walk that far.
To the place where the rally was, about a 15-minute walk to where the rally
Yeah, 15 to 30 minutes at most, depending how fast you're walking I would
When you same to D.C. on the 5th, right, for the 6th, were you expecting
there to be violence on January 6th?
You weren't expecting any violence with antifa or anything like that?
Well, Mr. Perna did say that, like, antifa rides around.
eyes open for them because they'll come up and jump you, stuff like that.
that, none like -- he never -- Mr. Perna or his buddies never once said:
to go out looking for violence or look for violence.
You got to watch for antifa because they'll come up on ya and jump
So, while you're preparing for that threat, how did you prepare, if at all?
Like, I didn't prepare anything differently.
I mean, I kept my -- if we
went out walking -- I know they had like a little thing going on, on the 5th.
down there, we went out and got like lunch or something, or, later on in the evening, we
But we went down, they had Freedom square or Plaza I think.
They had something going on there, so we walked down there and
And then, you know, we got -- when that was all ending, we stopped
and got a bite to eat and went back to our hotel room.
But you went to the rally at Freedom Plaza on January 5th?
How would you describe the environment during that rally?
You know, upbeat, playing music and stuff.
just hanging out, looking around, walking around.
Lincoln Memorial, seeing the Vietnam Memorial as well.
and then we walked around for a while.
We ended up walking over to the
So we spent a little time there,
And was there any speakers on the 5th that you were particularly excited to
I forgot to ask at the beginning.
see or that you were happy that you got to see after the fact?
I know there was some speakers going on.
remember that I thought was pretty cool was the rapper.
the speakers were, I mean, off the top of my head.
But, other than that, I'm not sure who
I guess, the night of January 5th leading into January 6th, do you recall the
President talking about Vice President Pence at that time or what he could do on the 6th?
Do you recall any conversations about that?
I remember hearing about it, how he can -- I don't know if he can say not
accept the electoral votes or something.
That had been about the only thing, you know,
that I would remember hearing that could have possibly happened.
Was that something that you were tracking or thinking about?
But, I mean, I probably -- as much as I followed politics, I
probably would have been watching for that or looking into that.
Only reason why I ask is because, as we get into the 6th, right, so Vice
President Pence then puts out the letter that he's not going to act on the certification of
I think I was -- at that point, I think I was believing, you know, it was basically
the whole system was rigged, you know?
seeing so much information put out that, whether it be true or not, you know, I was
believing at that time that, you know, it wasn't a legit election.
maybe was going to do that, but that's, you know, from the top of my head.
I can kind of remember I think.
At that point, I was definitely believing it after
Approximately, what time did you arrive at the Ellipse, if you remember?
That's where the rally was held.
What time did you arrive at the rally?
Is that where the rally was held?
I want to say we got there -- I'm not sure.
I'm talking like a D.C. local.
What time did the rally start, at
So President Trump spoke later in the morning, but the rally started much
I'm trying to understand when you arrived.
I want to say we maybe got there maybe a half hour, maybe
45 minutes -- like, I'm not even remembering a hundred percent right now.
say it wasn't long -- we weren't there -- we were standing around for a half hour,
45 minutes I would say, maybe even a little bit longer until Trump come on because we
were looking at T-shirts and stuff like that.
So you guys were outside of the security perimeter?
Did you stay for all of President Trump's speech?
Was -- anything about his speech stand out to you?
We weren't up inside where they had the perimeter up for the
We were there, and I think he stopped right around 1 o'clock.
The only thing I really remember is him saying,
"Hey, let's go down and show our disdain," or whatever.
Let's march on down to the Capitol and, you know, show your
previous rallies and stuff like that that I've seen online.
Other than that, it just seemed like the same stuff that he was repeating from his
Before this, though, you weren't tracking that people may be marching to
When you heard this, what did you think the point of going to the Capitol
I thought, you know, people were going to just go down there, stand around,
I don't remember hearing anything about that.
and basically be like a peaceful protest.
Well -- and I understand the peaceful protest.
At that time, I don't know if it would have been from stopping the steal, or if
they were, you know, hoping that the Vice President wouldn't accept the electorals.
not really sure technically what it would have been.
But, in your mind, you were going to protest the election, right, just to put it
So, when did you leave the rally, about 15 minutes after President Trump
We basically stood around for anywhere from 10 to 20 minutes, I'd
say 15 because that's probably ball park before we even started to head down there.
And do you remember the path you marched down to the Capitol Building?
We walked down that main road right there that was right in front of
Where the stage was set up, then you
had the security perimeter where everybody was sitting like in there, and then there was
right there, we followed that down.
And then you had the big field and the Washington Monument.
We were just following the crowd down, after we were, you know,
When did you come to understand that the Capitol Grounds might have
been breached, like the fencing or even the Building --
people when we got down there.
When I got down there, it was -- that whole place was overrun with
So you knew this before you got there, or did you see it as you were
I seen it as we were walking up.
I guess, what were you thinking as you were walking there?
running through your mind as you saw that scene?
Me, personally, I was just like more like a shock and awe, like holy, you
Kind of crazy, you know, there's people everywhere, you know.
I'm just going to ask one followup, I guess.
Just to see what it looked like.
Like, once we start getting down there, then
like -- from what I came up walking straight up, you seen people kind of clashing with the
cops over to the far -- it would have been my far right at the time, and I was just more
shocked to see what was going on.
Did people appear angry as you were walking to the Capitol?
Tell us some of the things they were saying, if you recall?
They were saying all types -- you know, people were screaming all types of
A lot of people -- a lot of people seemed like they were very upset.
They were mad that Vice President Pence was going to accept the electorals.
mean, it was -- it was -- if you could think it up, you were hearing it.
I don't know if I heard that or not, but I wouldn't be surprised if I did because
And I'm just going -- were you angry as well when you were marching
Did you share some of that anger?
I had some, like, sentiment like that.
But I wasn't like some of the
I was like, "Oh, man, this," you know, I was like, "This stinks," you
people completely fired up, acting crazy, and there was other people that are just like me
kind of like bummed out, more or less bummed out.
But there was a lot of people that -- there was
And why were you bummed out?
Just because, you know, it kind of got all pumped up like -- maybe Mr. Trump
or President Trump was gonna end up staying in office.
that -- or the Vice President Pence was, you know, approving it or whatever.
personally can remember feeling bummed out.
Then you find out he's doing
I wasn't really so much mad or cheated,
So, when you get to the Capitol, were there any barriers up when
When I got down there, I -- where we come in at, I don't remember seeing
have been hard to see anything.
started getting sandwiched in like sardines, and you were getting forced forward.
like, if you were walking up and you started getting up in there, you got pushed forward
anyways because it was packed pretty tight.
There was just so many people flooding the whole entire area.
And then, once you started walking in there, you
I guess, you said you saw people clashing with the law enforcement, like you
said, as you were walking up.
Did you see violence after you got on the Capitol Grounds approaching the
Approaching the Capitol Grounds -- walking up to the actual Capitol
Once I got there -- that -- I seen people kind of clashing with the police and
stuff, but it was up like a hundred yards up ahead of me, 150 yards up ahead of me, but
they were almost like up on top of the Capitol Building it itself.
And, when you got on the Capitol Grounds, did you see any
I did see people clashing with them then, once I got up closer.
When you got close to the Capitol, were people instructing you about going
towards the Capitol or how to get in the Capitol?
Did receive any instructions from any people?
There was a bunch of people with, like, bullhorns hollering stuff:
There was quite a few people that had bullhorns.
So, on top of that -- and you
know, people talking and people were chanting.
hard to take it all in, even to understand if somebody was trying to direct people any
And they were, you know -- people
It was kind of a really hectic situation.
Do you recall anything specific about the people with the blow horns?
They were just yelling, you know, basically, you know, the system's rigged
because, you know, of how crazy the day was.
I remember hearing stuff like that I want to say.
But I don't know if I heard
But I'm willing to bet there probably was
I guess, I forgot to ask this earlier.
Are you aware -- or, at this time, were you aware of groups like the Oath Keepers
